column3: fifty four.
one.

column2: What (Tao's) skilful planter plants Can never be uptorn; What his skilful arms enfold, From him can ne'er be borne. Sons shall bring in lengthening line, Sacrifices to his shrine.
column3: What (Tao's) skilful planter plants Can never be uptorn; What his skilful arms enfold, From him can ne'er be borne. Sons shall bring in lengthening line, Sacrifices to his shrine.
two.

column2: Tao when nursed within one's self, His vigour will make true; And where the family it rules What riches will accrue! The neighbourhood where it prevails In thriving will abound; And when 'tis seen throughout the state, Good fortune will be found. Employ it the kingdom o'er, And men thrive all around.
column3: Tao when nursed within one's self, His vigour will make true; And where the family it rules What riches will accrue! The neighbourhood where it prevails In thriving will abound; And when 'tis seen throughout the state, Good fortune will be found. Employ it the kingdom o'er, And men thrive all around.
three.

column2: In this way the effect will be seen in the person, by the observation of different cases; in the family; in the neighbourhood; in the state; and in the kingdom.
column3: In this way the effect will be seen in the person, by the observation of different cases; in the family; in the neighbourhood; in the state; and in the kingdom.
four.

column2: How do I know that this effect is sure to hold thus all under the sky?
column3: How do I know that this effect is sure to hold thus all under the sky?

column2: By this (method of observation).
column3: By this (method of observation).
fifty five.
one.

column2: He who has in himself abundantly the attributes (of the Tao) is like an infant.
column3: He who has in himself abundantly the attributes (of the Tao) is like an infant.

column2: Poisonous insects will not sting him; fierce beasts will not seize him; birds of prey will not strike him.
column3: Poisonous insects will not sting him; fierce beasts will not seize him; birds of prey will not strike him.
two.

column2: (The infant's) bones are weak and its sinews soft, but yet its grasp is firm.
column3: (The infant's) bones are weak and its sinews soft, but yet its grasp is firm.

column2: It knows not yet the union of male and female, and yet its virile member may be excited;--showing the perfection of its physical essence.
column3: It knows not yet the union of male and female, and yet its virile member may be excited;--showing the perfection of its physical essence.

column2: All day long it will cry without its throat becoming hoarse;--showing the harmony (in its constitution).
column3: All day long it will cry without its throat becoming hoarse;--showing the harmony (in its constitution).
three.

column2: To him by whom this harmony is known, (The secret of) the unchanging (Tao) is shown, And in the knowledge wisdom finds its throne. All life-increasing arts to evil turn; Where the mind makes the vital breath to burn, (False) is the strength, (and o'er it we should mourn.)
column3: To him by whom this harmony is known, (The secret of) the unchanging (Tao) is shown, And in the knowledge wisdom finds its throne. All life increasing arts to evil turn; Where the mind makes the vital breath to burn, (False) is the strength, (and o'er it we should mourn.)
four.

column2: When things have become strong, they (then) become old, which may be said to be contrary to the Tao.
column3: When things have become strong, they (then) become old, which may be said to be contrary to the Tao.

column2: Whatever is contrary to the Tao soon ends.
column3: Whatever is contrary to the Tao soon ends.
fifty six.
one.

column2: He who knows (the Tao) does not (care to) speak (about it); he who is (ever ready to) speak about it does not know it.
column3: He who knows (the Tao) does not (care to) speak (about it); he who is (ever ready to) speak about it does not know it.
two.

column2: He (who knows it) will keep his mouth shut and close the portals (of his nostrils).
column3: He (who knows it) will keep his mouth shut and close the portals (of his nostrils).

column2: He will blunt his sharp points and unravel the complications of things; he will attemper his brightness, and bring himself into agreement with the obscurity (of others).
column3: He will blunt his sharp points and unravel the complications of things; he will attemper his brightness, and bring himself into agreement with the obscurity (of others).

column2: This is called 'the Mysterious Agreement.'
column3: This is called 'the Mysterious Agreement.'
three.

column2: (Such an one) cannot be treated familiarly or distantly; he is beyond all consideration of profit or injury; of nobility or meanness:--he is the noblest man under heaven.
column3: (Such an one) cannot be treated familiarly or distantly; he is beyond all consideration of profit or injury; of nobility or meanness:--he is the noblest man under heaven.
fifty seven.
one.

column2: A state may be ruled by (measures of) correction; weapons of war may be used with crafty dexterity; (but) the kingdom is made one's own (only) by freedom from action and purpose.
column3: A state may be ruled by (measures of) correction; weapons of war may be used with crafty dexterity; (but) the kingdom is made one's own (only) by freedom from action and purpose.
two.

column2: How do I know that it is so?
column3: How do I know that it is so?

column2: By these facts:--In the kingdom the multiplication of prohibitive enactments increases the poverty of the people; the more implements to add to their profit that the people have, the greater disorder is there in the state and clan; the more acts of crafty dexterity that men possess, the more do strange contrivances appear; the more display there is of legislation, the more thieves and robbers there are.
column3: By these facts:--In the kingdom the multiplication of prohibitive enactments increases the poverty of the people; the more implements to add to their profit that the people have, the greater disorder is there in the state and clan; the more acts of crafty dexterity that men possess, the more do strange contrivances appear; the more display there is of legislation, the more thieves and robbers there are.
three.

column2: Therefore a sage has said, 'I will do nothing (of purpose), and the people will be transformed of themselves; I will be fond of keeping still, and the people will of themselves become correct.
column3: Therefore a sage has said, 'I will do nothing (of purpose), and the people will be transformed of themselves; I will be fond of keeping still, and the people will of themselves become correct.

column2: I will take no trouble about it, and the people will of themselves become rich; I will manifest no ambition, and the people will of themselves attain to the primitive simplicity.'
column3: I will take no trouble about it, and the people will of themselves become rich; I will manifest no ambition, and the people will of themselves attain to the primitive simplicity.'
fifty eight.
one.

column2: The government that seems the most unwise, Oft goodness to the people best supplies; That which is meddling, touching everything, Will work but ill, and disappointment bring.
column3: The government that seems the most unwise, Oft goodness to the people best supplies; That which is meddling, touching everything, Will work but ill, and disappointment bring.

column2: Misery!--happiness is to be found by its side!
column3: Misery!--happiness is to be found by its side!

column2: Happiness!--misery lurks beneath it!
column3: Happiness!--misery lurks beneath it!

column2: Who knows what either will come to in the end?
column3: Who knows what either will come to in the end?
two.

column2: Shall we then dispense with correction?
column3: Shall we then dispense with correction?

column2: The (method of) correction shall by a turn become distortion, and the good in it shall by a turn become evil.
column3: The (method of) correction shall by a turn become distortion, and the good in it shall by a turn become evil.

column2: The delusion of the people (on this point) has indeed subsisted for a long time.
column3: The delusion of the people (on this point) has indeed subsisted for a long time.
three.

column2: Therefore the sage is (like) a square which cuts no one (with its angles); (like) a corner which injures no one (with its sharpness). He is straightforward, but allows himself no license; he is bright, but does not dazzle.
column3: Therefore the sage is (like) a square which cuts no one (with its angles); (like) a corner which injures no one (with its sharpness). He is straightforward, but allows himself no license; he is bright, but does not dazzle.
fifty nine.
one.

column2: For regulating the human (in our constitution) and rendering the (proper) service to the heavenly, there is nothing like moderation.
column3: For regulating the human (in our constitution) and rendering the (proper) service to the heavenly, there is nothing like moderation.
two.

column2: It is only by this moderation that there is effected an early return (to man's normal state).
column3: It is only by this moderation that there is effected an early return (to man's normal state).

column2: That early return is what I call the repeated accumulation of the attributes (of the Tao).
column3: That early return is what I call the repeated accumulation of the attributes (of the Tao).

column2: With that repeated accumulation of those attributes, there comes the subjugation (of every obstacle to such return).
column3: With that repeated accumulation of those attributes, there comes the subjugation (of every obstacle to such return).

column2: Of this subjugation we know not what shall be the limit; and when one knows not what the limit shall be, he may be the ruler of a state.
column3: Of this subjugation we know not what shall be the limit; and when one knows not what the limit shall be, he may be the ruler of a state.
three.

column2: He who possesses the mother of the state may continue long.
column3: He who possesses the mother of the state may continue long.

column2: His case is like that (of the plant) of which we say that its roots are deep and its flower stalks firm:--this is the way to secure that its enduring life shall long be seen.
column3: His case is like that (of the plant) of which we say that its roots are deep and its flower stalks firm:--this is the way to secure that its enduring life shall long be seen.
sixty.
one.

column2: Governing a great state is like cooking small fish.
column3: Governing a great state is like cooking small fish.
two.

column2: Let the kingdom be governed according to the Tao, and the manes of the departed will not manifest their spiritual energy.
column3: Let the kingdom be governed according to the Tao, and the manes of the departed will not manifest their spiritual energy.

column2: It is not that those manes have not that spiritual energy, but it will not be employed to hurt men.
column3: It is not that those manes have not that spiritual energy, but it will not be employed to hurt men.

column2: It is not that it could not hurt men, but neither does the ruling sage hurt them.
column3: It is not that it could not hurt men, but neither does the ruling sage hurt them.
three.

column2: When these two do not injuriously affect each other, their good influences converge in the virtue (of the Tao).
column3: When these two do not injuriously affect each other, their good influences converge in the virtue (of the Tao).
sixty one.
one.

column2: What makes a great state is its being (like) a low-lying, down-flowing (stream);--it becomes the centre to which tend (all the small states) under heaven.
column3: What makes a great state is its being (like) a low lying, down flowing (stream);--it becomes the centre to which tend (all the small states) under heaven.
two.

column2: (To illustrate from) the case of all females:--the female always overcomes the male by her stillness.
column3: (To illustrate from) the case of all females:--the female always overcomes the male by her stillness.

column2: Stillness may be considered (a sort of) abasement.
column3: Stillness may be considered (a sort of) abasement.
three.

column2: Thus it is that a great state, by condescending to small states, gains them for itself; and that small states, by abasing themselves to a great state, win it over to them.
column3: Thus it is that a great state, by condescending to small states, gains them for itself; and that small states, by abasing themselves to a great state, win it over to them.

column2: In the one case the abasement leads to gaining adherents, in the other case to procuring favour.
column3: In the one case the abasement leads to gaining adherents, in the other case to procuring favour.
four.

column2: The great state only wishes to unite men together and nourish them; a small state only wishes to be received by, and to serve, the other. Each gets what it desires, but the great state must learn to abase itself.
column3: The great state only wishes to unite men together and nourish them; a small state only wishes to be received by, and to serve, the other. Each gets what it desires, but the great state must learn to abase itself.
sixty two.
one.

column2: Tao has of all things the most honoured place. No treasures give good men so rich a grace; Bad men it guards, and doth their ill efface.
column3: Tao has of all things the most honoured place. No treasures give good men so rich a grace; Bad men it guards, and doth their ill efface.
two.

column2: (Its) admirable words can purchase honour; (its) admirable deeds can raise their performer above others.
column3: (Its) admirable words can purchase honour; (its) admirable deeds can raise their performer above others.

column2: Even men who are not good are not abandoned by it.
column3: Even men who are not good are not abandoned by it.
three.

column2: Therefore when the sovereign occupies his place as the Son of Heaven, and he has appointed his three ducal ministers, though (a prince) were to send in a round symbol-of-rank large enough to fill both the hands, and that as the precursor of the team of horses (in the court-yard), such an offering would not be equal to (a lesson of) this Tao, which one might present on his knees.
column3: Therefore when the sovereign occupies his place as the Son of Heaven, and he has appointed his three ducal ministers, though (a prince) were to send in a round symbol of rank large enough to fill both the hands, and that as the precursor of the team of horses (in the court yard), such an offering would not be equal to (a lesson of) this Tao, which one might present on his knees.
four.

column2: Why was it that the ancients prized this Tao so much?
column3: Why was it that the ancients prized this Tao so much?

column2: Was it not because it could be got by seeking for it, and the guilty could escape (from the stain of their guilt) by it?
column3: Was it not because it could be got by seeking for it, and the guilty could escape (from the stain of their guilt) by it?

column2: This is the reason why all under heaven consider it the most valuable thing.
column3: This is the reason why all under heaven consider it the most valuable thing.
sixty three.
one.

column2: (It is the way of the Tao) to act without (thinking of) acting; to conduct affairs without (feeling the) trouble of them; to taste without discerning any flavour; to consider what is small as great, and a few as many; and to recompense injury with kindness.
column3: (It is the way of the Tao) to act without (thinking of) acting; to conduct affairs without (feeling the) trouble of them; to taste without discerning any flavour; to consider what is small as great, and a few as many; and to recompense injury with kindness.
two.

column2: (The master of it) anticipates things that are difficult while they are easy, and does things that would become great while they are small.
column3: (The master of it) anticipates things that are difficult while they are easy, and does things that would become great while they are small.

column2: All difficult things in the world are sure to arise from a previous state in which they were easy, and all great things from one in which they were small.
column3: All difficult things in the world are sure to arise from a previous state in which they were easy, and all great things from one in which they were small.

column2: Therefore the sage, while he never does what is great, is able on that account to accomplish the greatest things.
column3: Therefore the sage, while he never does what is great, is able on that account to accomplish the greatest things.
three.

column2: He who lightly promises is sure to keep but little faith; he who is continually thinking things easy is sure to find them difficult. Therefore the sage sees difficulty even in what seems easy, and so never has any difficulties.
column3: He who lightly promises is sure to keep but little faith; he who is continually thinking things easy is sure to find them difficult. Therefore the sage sees difficulty even in what seems easy, and so never has any difficulties.
sixty four.
one.

column2: That which is at rest is easily kept hold of; before a thing has given indications of its presence, it is easy to take measures against it; that which is brittle is easily broken; that which is very small is easily dispersed.
column3: That which is at rest is easily kept hold of; before a thing has given indications of its presence, it is easy to take measures against it; that which is brittle is easily broken; that which is very small is easily dispersed.

column2: Action should be taken before a thing has made its appearance; order should be secured before disorder has begun.
column3: Action should be taken before a thing has made its appearance; order should be secured before disorder has begun.
